comments:
I20050112-1200

This is probably a user error but I can't get the command line arguments: as
described in Javadoc Platform.getCommandLineArgs() might not contain all
entries, which is true in my scenario. I then tried to get the command line
arguments using:
EnvironmentInfo.getDefault().getCommandLineArgs() but this fails telling that
the class EnvironmentInfo can't be found (see below). I've added
org.eclipse.osgi to the required list. The plug-in (org.eclipse.jdt.ui) also
requires the compatibility layer.

Caused by: java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError:
org/eclipse/core/runtime/adaptor/EnvironmentInfo
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.JavaPlugin.start(JavaPlugin.java:376)
	at
org.eclipse.core.internal.compatibility.PluginActivator.start(PluginActivator.java:30)
	at
org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.BundleContextImpl$1.run(BundleContextImpl.java:958)
	at java.security.AccessController.doPrivileged(Native Method)
	at
org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.BundleContextImpl.startActivator(BundleContextImpl.java:954)
	... 58 more

org.eclipse.runtime.adaptor.EnvironmentInfo is an internal class (see the tiny
comment at the top of the class) and is the implementation of the
org.eclipse.osgi.service.environment.EnvironmentInfo service (in the osgi sense).

For an example on how to acquire this service (or any other) see
Platform.acquireInfoService().
